lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about Anna’s toy (the matryoshka doll) and find key details such as color and number.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read 1 sentence aloud. Ask: “What toy is that?” or “What colour?”
stretchStrategies: Have students draw a “My special toy” picture. Then they walk around the room asking, “What colour is it?” and answering with “It’s ___.” using each other’s drawings.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write the letters c, a, t, p to form simple words.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Write “cat,” “pat,” “cap” on board. Say slowly. Students clap syllables.
stretchStrategies: Have students draw a “My special toy” picture. Then they walk around the room asking, “What colour is it?” and answering with “It’s ___.” using each other’s drawings.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Social studies Students can learn that the special doll (matryoshka) comes from Russia and say one fact about it.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Show matryoshka in SB. Say: “This is from Russia.” Ask: “Big or small?”
stretchStrategies: Have students draw a “My special toy” picture. Then they walk around the room asking, “What colour is it?” and answering with “It’s ___.” using each other’s drawings.

items: VYL: colours do not map onto one another (blue/green = blue)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
